Comment: e4! What a surprise!
Ooh - my opponent replies with the Scandinavian Defence.
So I take.
The most common move is 2. ... Qxd5, is it not? But Nf6 is OK.
Nc3, one of many common moves.
Bf4: again, still common.
d4! Is this a little bit on the stubborn side, maybe?
c5?? Apparently, my opponent does not want my d4 pawn to be on the d4 square.
So I take.
e6? I can see his objective: to get rid of my strong centre pawns - again, that's why you shouldn't play Scandinavia. But in one look, why not 6. d6.
And the mighty pawn advances! Nothing, not a pawn, can take it.
My opponent wants to develop his DSB through fianchetto.
And I pin his knight. Too, frightfully, common.
He develops.
Qd2. Again, quite common. If 8. ... O-O 9. Bh6, making a hole on the dark squares in Black's home. Sincerely, it's not that bad, but it's not that good either.
He develops his queen's knight, at last.
And I pin his knight, again! Yet again, too common.
He defends his knight, and preparing for an attack down the queenside.
And I castle queenside. A bit risky, I admit, but the c-file's not actually 'open'.
He wants to chase away my bishop.
